awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  BioTechnology Sequencing-based Undergraduate Research Experience (BIT SURE)
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to North Carolina State University (NCSU), located in Raleigh, NC, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers 2018-2020.  The Biotechnology (BIT) Sequencing-based Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE) immerses students in research that uses next generation sequencing (NGS) to answer important biological questions.  NCSU's interdisciplinary BIT Program, which combines researchers, educators and students from 35 departments, will sponsor BIT SURE. Research mentors will engage students in projects across a variety of fields including microbiology, virology, neuroscience, plant biology, epigenetics, genomics, etc. Trainees will begin with a NGS short course where they will receive laboratory safety training, work on NGS case studies, prepare samples for sequencing, and analyze data using common bioinformatic tools and software. Participants will also attend seminars on NGS research, biotech careers, graduate school, responsible conduct of research, and visit biotech companies in Research Triangle Park.  

It is anticipated that a total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program.  Recruitment will focus on underrepresented groups in STEM, including deaf/hard of hearing students, first generation college students, minorities and students with no prior research experience.  Students will learn how research is conducted, and many will present the results of their work at scientific conferences.  Trainees will also work together to present a deaf accessible K-12 outreach activity to students from the North Carolina School for the Deaf.  Through building accessible educational resources and the recruitment and training of underrepresented groups, BIT SURE aims to inspire and support a diverse group of students in future biotechnology-related research careers.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths and be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. More information about the program is available by visiting http://biotech.ncsu.edu or by contacting the PI (Dr. Sabrina Robertson, sedought@ncsu.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. Carlos Goller, ccgoller@ncsu.edu).

por.por_cntn:
The NSF BIoTechnology-based Sequencing-based Undergraduate Research Experience (BIT SURE) Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) had the goals of training diverse groups of students for biotechnology-related careers using high-throughput DNA sequencing technologies. Over the course of three summers, the program trained 33 undergraduate students in the use of sequence analysis tools and preparation of samples for sequencing. We recruited eager students from across the country and through dynamic collaborations with the National Technical Institute for the Deaf (in Rochester Institute of Technology) and Gallaudet University, we recruited and trained eight Deaf and Hard of Hearing participants. Ten mentors exposed students to the use of sequencing approaches to improve agricultural practices, bioremediation of contaminated waters, selection of trees with desirable characteristics, drosophila genetics, and biofuels. A team of five interpreters over the course of three summers worked to facilitate communication for all participants in the program. Service team outreach workshops (STOW) led to the creation of educational lessons and resources to teach students of all ages about the significance and applications of sequencing technologies. In the summer of 2018, BIT SURE participants used the activities they designed to engage students in summer programs at the North Carolina School for the Deaf. In the summer of 2019, REU participants created tactile teaching tools with Braille and electronic elements to expose learners to sophisticated sequencing approaches. In 2021, STOW taught students about the importance of backward design and universal design for learning. Students formed smaller groups to create case studies, presentations, and websites to teach students about novel applications of sequencing. BIT SURE REU participants learned valuable concepts through short courses that included lab components in 2018 and 2019 and a series of bioinformatics workshops when the program was virtual in 2021. Participants indicated gains in confidence to perform research and increased familiarity with bioinformatics tools for sequence analysis. In 2021 alone, BIT SURE REU participants completed forty workshops, seminars, panels, and training sessions on ethics, the undergraduate research experience, and careers with biotechnology and sequencing. Three graduate teaching assistants helped facilitate hands-on lab sessions to prepare sequencing libraries and bioinformatics workshops using powerful cloud computing resources. Five undergraduate students helped the BIT SURE REU program with logistics, dissemination of information, and community building. BIT SURE REU alumni continue to progress in their careers, presenting at national conferences, enrolling in graduate school programs, and entering the workforce to use bioinformatics and lab-based skills gained through this summer program. 

Thus, the NSF BIT SURE REU experience equipped life science students with the appropriate skills, knowledge, and confidence to effectively use sequencing technologies and analyze the resulting data sets. The program trained diverse students capable of explaining the applications of high-throughput sequencing approaches and appropriately using these technologies to tackle scientific challenges. Importantly, BIT SURE REU engaged participants in sharing their research and newly acquired knowledge with the academic community and, through educational outreach, with K-12 Deaf and Hard-of-hearing students (D/HH).
